item.title: Estimation Error Visualized
item.description: The objective of economic models is to dress common-sense into mathematical formalism1. For some economic models, however, real data is too scare to achieve good statistical analysis. This scarcity of data leads to estimation-error2 (the econometricians enemy number one). By estimation-error I mean: the researcher is never certain about the true data generating process (DGP) of the phenomenon at hand. As Allan Timmermann and Graham Elliott argue, economic models can be thought as a condense representation of reality, in which mispecifification flourish naturally3.

item.title: How much shrinkage does the stock market requires?
item.description: Shrinkage is hardly new in finance. In 1956, Charles Stein published a famous paper called Inadmissibility of the usual estimator for the mean of a multivariate normal distribution. In his work, he shows that, if the sum of the squares of the errors (SSE) is used as a loss function, then, for $ n \geq 2 $, the sample mean is not an optimal estimator. It can be improved by exploring the trade-off among bias and variance.
